_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68, and other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility. Our goal is to promote worker, public, and plant safety!





This is a full 5 year RMP submittal for the Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream facility, located at 3426 Wells Street, Fort Wayne, Indiana. We manufacture some of the finest packaged ice cream and ice cream snacks in the world. In addition, the facility stores and ships many Nestle products that require frozen storage. Some of the equipment in the facility includes processing tanks, piping, packaging equipment, raw materials warehousing, two ammonia refrigeration engine rooms (process and warehouse), refrigerated storage, boilers, and miscellaneous utilities. Also located at the facility is raw milk processing equipment, shipping and receiving docks, and a waste water treatment equalization system. The facility produces and ships millions of pounds of products each year.





The refrigeration system required for our facility necessitates the submission of this Risk Management Plan. The refrigeration system contains in excess of 77,500 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. This surpasses the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds outlined in Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program regulations.





Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream has implemented numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences of, significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia to the atmosphere. The plant also has many policies and procedures to minimize the potential for catastrophic accidents involving

around any other hazardous substances, fires, or explosions., and other types of catastrophic accidents.





Our safety programs focus on the rules, procedures, and practices that govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment. These rules are detailed and improved as necessary. They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at our facility.





DESCRIPTION OF THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



In the event that an ammonia leak is detected, employees are to notify the onsite Refrigeration Technicians, who are Hazmat Responders. The Hazmat Responder takes an ammonia level reading using a detection device. If the Hazmat Responder determines that the ammonia level is above 35 ppm, an evacuation of the exposure area is ordered. If an evacuation is necessary, an Incident Commander takes control of the situation.





The Hazmat Responder and/or Incident Commander will determines if the leak is serious enough that outside assistance is needed. If outside assistance is needed, the local HAZMAT organization is contacted and the internal Hazmat/Emergency Response Team is mobilized.

The Hazmat Responders then take appropriate action to mitigate the leak. They are trained in plant procedures, such as Emergency Shutdown Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's), to control the leak with appropriate personal protective devices in place.





Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream to remain an industry leader, especially in safety. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system. As part of ongoing training, Nestle Dreyer's Hazmat responders train with the local HAZMAT responders (Fort Wayne Fire Department) at our facility.





PSM PROGRAM



Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream has organized the information and po

lices pertaining to the refrigeration process into a complete PSM library consisting of nine numbered volumes. Some of these volume numbers are assigned to sets of reference manuals, such as Operation and Maintenance manuals. This library also incorporates the use of videos and computerized tests. A description is as follows:





Volume IA of the PSM/RMP Library incorporates mainly policies, including the following:





Employee Participation Guidelines: This policy outlines the commitment between management and employees to establish a program for a successful and safe program.





Process Safety Information: This includes information on the ammonia inventory at the facility, applicable codes, design standards, and information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia (referenced from the IIAR ammonia Data Book).





Process Hazard Analysis Program: This program outlines a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards within a process involving potentially hazardous chemicals such as ammonia.





Training: Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream has implemented a robust training program for all of the Refrigeration Technicians. The plan is for 100% of the Refrigeration Technicians to be RETA CIRO certified at the end of a 2-year training program. In addition, the training includes videos, tests, hands on demonstrations, SOP reviews, etc.





Contractor Qualification Guidelines: This guideline has been established to verify that the contractors working in the facility are qualified to work on the system, trained in the hazards associated with their work, and made aware of the hazards presented by the facility to the employees of the contractor. Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs: These programs have been developed to monitor and provide a "check and balance" system to monitor changes in the facility and to verify that changes are safe and consistent with company policy.





Line Break Program

: This has been developed to ensure that the system is safe to work on whenever maintenance is needed. It includes the ammonia system, but also includes compressed air, chemicals, natural gas, steam, etc. The line break permit must be used whenever any work is done in this area.





Ammonia Work Procedure: The plant has many requirements that must be met whenever work is done on the ammonia system, and are included in this section. This includes communication, work order details, personal protective equipment (PPE), oil draining process, etc.





Many more specific programs and policies (Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout, additional Employee training, etc.) have been developed. For information specific to these see the Safety, Health, and Environmental Manager or the PSM Coordinator. The plant has attained OHSAS 18001 and ISO 14001 Certifications.





Volume II incorporates information on the specific system components of the production area refrigeration equipment. This information is used as a reference source for the operator to positively identify system components. This manual also provides a checklist for performing the yearly Mechanical Integrity Inspection.





Volume III incorporates a complete valve list, process and instrumentation diagrams, flow schematics, and other drawing pertinent to the production area refrigeration equipment. The valve list contains information on the type, port , identifying number, use, location, model, manufacturer, drawing reference, and normal operating position of each valve in the system. Process and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&ID's) are included for the individual system components. Flow schematics are included showing the entire system. A Block flow diagram provides a brief overview of the system. Drawings are included showing symbol and abbreviation descriptions. Plan views are included to allow the operator to physically locate equipment in the building.





Volume IV incorporates a complete set of standard

Operating Procedures (SOP's) for the production area refrigeration equipment, describing the proper steps for preparing components for start-up, starting components, monitoring normal operation, shutting down as part of normal operation, restarting equipment as part of normal operation, shutting down equipment for maintenance, restarting equipment after maintenance, shutting down equipment in emergency situations, restarting equipment after an emergency situations shutdown, and pump-out procedures. Each Standard Operating Procedure also includes the Technical Operating Specifications, possible consequences of deviation from standard operating procedures, and lock-out/tag-out procedures





Volume V contains Operation and Maintenance Information for the production area refrigeration equipment including manufacturer's information, spare parts list, maintenance procedures, and preventative maintenance procedures.





Volume VI incorporates information on the specific system components of the warehouse refrigeration equipment (similar to Volume II).





Volume VII incorporates a complete valve list, process and instrumentation diagrams, flow schematics, and other drawing pertinent to the warehouse area refrigeration equipment (similar to Volume III).





Volume VIII incorporates a complete set of standard operating procedures for the warehouse area refrigeration equipment (similar to Volume IV).





Volume IX contains Operation and Maintenance Information for the warehouse area refrigeration equipment including manufactures information, spare parts list, maintenance procedures, and preventative maintenance procedures (similar to Volume V).





A full Process Hazard Analysis was performed in April 2015 for the Process refrigeration system. The PHA team made several recommendations to improve safety and operations. These items have been prioritized and addressed as part of the continuous improvement of the facility. 

A full Process Hazard Analysis was performed in

November 2013 for the Warehouse refrigeration system. The PHA team made recommendations to improve safety and operations. These items will be addressed and prioritized for completion in a timely manner, as part of the continuous improvement of the facility. Items of a low priority (Process improvements) will be budgeted for completion in a timely manner.





A full Compliance Audit was performed in late August 2016 on the PSM/RMP Program. The Audit team made several recommendations to improve safety and operations. These items have been prioritized and addressed as part of the continuous improvement of the facility.





Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream ammonia refrigeration system also incorporates additional safety items such as tagging of all valves and components, ammonia detection system, a robust PM system, and a PC / PLC based control system with a graphical operator interface that controls mitigating devices such as emergency exhaust fans, emergency shutdown systems and alarms. Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream also records and investigates any and all ammonia leaks, no matter how minor. Root causes are determined, and counter measures such as preventative maintenance (PM's) are implemented in order to prevent any future occurrences.





DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITIES PRODUCTION AND WAREHOUSE REFRIGERATION SYSTEMS





The Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Production and Warehouse systems incorporate a standard evaporation and compression style Ammonia Refrigeration systems. 





SUMMARY OF THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY





Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream had 1 reportable release of more than 100 pounds in a 24 hour period in the last 5 years.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream holds monthly PSM team Meetings, led by the on-site PSM Coordinator. The facility has OSHA Process Safety Management and EPA Risk Management Programs, and has a partnership with a local contractor who specializes in these areas. The facility also

has ongoing training, including a specialized training program for the Refrigeration techs that work on the ammonia system. Other items include annual Mechanical Integrity Inspections, PSM/RMP Compliance Audits as required every 3 years, Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) as required, Emergency Response Training and Practice Drills, Management of Change Program, ,Lock-out/Tag-out Program, Hot Work Program, and the Line Break program. All programs are continuously reviewed and improved on a regular basis.





Nestle Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream is committed to safety of its employees and surrounding

community.
